Award.AwardTitle: DIP: Collaborative Research: Impact of Adaptive Interventions on Student Affect, Performance and Learning

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
A major factor influencing learning is students' emotions and their general affective state. Given the pivotal role that affect plays in learning activities it is not surprising that there has been a good deal of interest in developing affect-aware technologies. The overwhelming majority of this work, however, has focused on modeling affect, i.e., designing computational models capable of inferring how students are feeling while interacting with an Intelligent Tutoring System (ITS). While modeling of affect is a critical first step in providing adaptive support tailored to students' affective needs, very little work exists on systematically exploring the impact of affective interventions on students' performance, learning, affect and attitudes, i.e., how to respond to students' emotions such as frustration, anxiety, boredom, and hopelessness as they arise. The research fills this gap by analyzing the value of tailoring different types of interventions to negative affective states for individual students and groups of students.

The project has two main goals. First, it addresses how to respond to negative student emotion (e.g., frustration, anxiety, boredom) in computer-based learning environments through a variety of interventions. Some correspond to specially-designed digital characters, integrated into the learning environment, which are intended to act like students' learning companions. These agents support students through (a) non-verbal behaviors (e.g., having the characters express empathy in response to student frustration), (b) messages targeting students' cognitive and meta-cognitive skills, as well as motivation and affect. Other interventions involve supporting collaboration between students to mitigate negative emotional states when detected. The impact of these interventions are investigated through a series of eight experiments with a total of 800 students. These experiments help to unveil general prescriptive principles to address student affect.

The second goal accomplished by this research is that the experiments provide valuable data to continue to extend and validate existing models of emotion. Specifically, the project triangulates and integrates a complex space of partially overlapping models and constructs of affect in learning (i.e. emotions, attitudes, incoming moods, motivation, engaged use or misuse of software). The project refines several well-established models, in particular the control-value theory of emotions to provide a more stable theoretical framework for the field of emotions in educational software.

This research is unique and ground breaking, as few researchers have targeted students' emotion in classrooms, gathered fine grained data on emotions during learning, or assessed the impact of specific affective treatments on a moment-to-moment basis. Students using the tutoring systems have already shown statistically significant gains and learning outcomes, as well as increased positive affect and attitudes. The new affective interventions will greatly increase the broad impact of these systems.
This research is developing: (1) prescriptive principles about how to respond to student affect; (2) new understanding about the impact of cognitive, affective, and meta-cognitive interventions on emotions and learning; (3) new understanding about individual differences in learning, unveiling the extent to which emotion, cognitive abilities, and gender impact learning; (4) instruction that is sensitive to individual differences; and (5) refined theories of student emotion.

This research is also: (1) increasing participation in mathematics of underrepresented populations (women and minorities) who often avoid STEM careers; (2) creating broad access to web-based technologies that help to engage more students by addressing their affective and social needs; and (3) addressing the one-size-fits-all approach to education, by responding to individual student needs with alternative representations of content and pathways through which material is presented.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research analyzed the value of tailoring different types of interventions for individual students in an online tutor. The system recognized student emotion, such as frustration, boredom, confidence, and excitement, used different interventions to respond to the students and then measured learning improvement. We tested animated characters, supporting collaboration between students, and various messages (e.g., empathic or simply correct or not) to identify which is most effective when students become disengaged.

This research was conducted within an intelligent mathematics tutor for grades 5-12 called MathSpring, used by thousands of students and able to generate improved learning gains and accelerated results on state-standard exams. The tutor assessed individual students’ knowledge and effort and provided individualized problem and help accordingly.  It also provided hints and explanations, tutorial videos, and animated worked-out examples.

We analyzed students’ affective comments, in particular what students meant when they said they were “frustrated”, “interested”, “anxious”, etc. and what were the reasons for the emotions they reported. Students self-reported their affect and explained why they were feeling that way using an open-ended response dialog box. Students tended to attribute a specific emotion to a variety of reasons, not a single reason.

The results suggested that using an animated character that was empathic and emphasized the malleability of intelligence and the importance of effort provided enhanced student learning and reduced boredom and anxiety. 

Students described their particular affective states and we hand coded and analyzed their text. A prevalence of students externalized their affect, especially negative valence emotions. They attributing perceived difficulty of the problem and their own negativity as lying outside of themselves. In one dataset, students were more likely to report that the material was “difficult” when reporting high interest or excitement than when reporting low interest or excitement.

Results suggested that using animated characters that were empathic to the student’s effort (versus students’ success) provided enhanced student learning, and reduced boredom and anxiety. However, emphasizing only success (e.g., “You are right/wrong”) was detrimental to learning an interest and promoted anxiety. Additionally, there may be other possible internal attributions students may offer when they do poorly, e.g., a high percentage of student attribute failure to “low interest”. This type of dis-interest may be distinct from that of students who report low interest when attributing it to external causes (e.g., easy problems) in the case of success.

The group in the External & Low performing quadrant reported the most frustration, and the least interest at a statistically significant level, but also the highest confidence with marginal significance. Perhaps these students worked harder and derived confidence from their efforts. Meanwhile students in the Internal & Low performing group reported the significantly highest degree of interest, suggesting that they may be more engaged by the material. The data seemed to suggest that the externalizing group experienced reduced confidence and interest due to low item difficulty, while the same seems less true of the internalizing group. As a result they may respond differently to treatment.

Some of the results were aligned to expectations in the literature: animated characters delivered growth mindset messages (e.g., help students reflect on their errors and focus on personal progress) and reduced performance-approach goals (e.g., to beat classmates instead of self-referenced focus). This suggested that growth mindset messages worked according to what they were supposed to accomplish. What was not expected was that growth mindset messages would provide an apparent boost in student math learning. Empathetic characters decreased students’ anxiety as well as boredom. Learning companions that showed empathy helped with students’ negative affective states, in particular anxiety and boredom and yielded higher math performance and learning.

Success/failure messages were harmful to students. Regardless of whether messages indicated success or failure, the more students were exposed to these kinds of messages, the higher the boredom and anxiety they developed, the higher performance oriented goals they develop, and the lower learning they exhibit at posttest time.

In sum, we found that: 1) students listened to the messages of affective characters, even when they were not sophisticated 3D characters and not realistic and did not process sophisticated natural language processing; 2) the learning and emotional benefits for students are due to empathy, first, and due to growth mindset (motivational) messages second, specifically on performance/learning orientation; and 3) the results on learning and emotion of a tutor that indicates only success or failure appeared to be harmful.

We conclude that characters within learning environments such as intelligent tutoring systems are, either explicitly or implicitly, powerful transmitters of affective messages, with repercussions shown in students’ affective states and  affective predispositions.
